comment_text.mn141:2.1: This is in reference to the Dhammacakkappavattanasutta, the so-called First Sermon (SN 56.11), for which the current discourse serves as a canonical commentary.
comment_text.mn141:3.1: The four noble truths are sometimes said to be like a doctor who identifies the illness, discerns its cause, understands the recovery, and administers the cure until the patient is restored to health (SA 389 at T ii 105a25; SA-2 254 at T ii 462c10). This analogy is not found in the Pali canon.
comment_text.mn141:5.4: To extol his leading students, the Buddha recalls his own upbringing, born of Māyā and raised by Mahāpajāpatī (who appears in the next discourse). Nonetheless, janetā is a masculine noun and it would be misleading to translate it as “mother”. Both mother and father “give birth” (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 6.4.14; the creator is male at 1.4.4).
comment_text.mn141:5.5: Āpādetā is a causative agent noun from ā + √pad in the sense “one who raises”. Again, both mother and father are “raisers” (āpādakā) of the child (AN 4.63:2.6).
comment_text.mn141:11.1: Here Sāriputta takes the analysis a step further than the Dhammacakkappavattanasutta. This extended analysis of the truths was adopted from here into DN 22:18.4, which further expanded the sections on the second and third noble truths in Abhidhamma style shared with Vb 4. | The definitions of rebirth, old age, and death are standard in dependent origination (SN 12.2:4.2), and are taught by Sāriputta also at MN 9:22.2.
comment_text.mn141:20.1: The five aggregates sum up the entirety of suffering, since all suffering is experienced within and by means of the aggregates.
comment_text.mn141:21.1: The second and third noble truths are here analyzed to the same level of depth as the First Sermon, with no further definition of terms. See MN 9:16.2 for notes.
comment_text.mn141:24.2: From here we have the standard definitions of the items of the noble eightfold path (SN 45.8:3.2; compare MN 117). | Ignorance is described in the opposite way (MN 9:64–66.7, SN 12.2:14.2).
comment_text.mn141:26.1: The items of right speech and right action are covered in greater detail under the ten pathways of skilful deeds at MN 41:12.4.

root_text.mn141:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā bārāṇasiyaṁ viharati isipatane migadāye.
root_text.mn141:2.1: “Tathāgatena, bhikkhave, arahatā sammāsambuddhena bārāṇasiyaṁ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṁ dhammacakkaṁ pavattitaṁ appaṭivattiyaṁ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṁ, yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn141:2.2: catunnaṁ ariyasaccānaṁ ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ.
root_text.mn141:3.1: Dukkhassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ, dukkhasamudayassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ, dukkhanirodhassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ.
root_text.mn141:4.1: Tathāgatena, bhikkhave, arahatā sammāsambuddhena bārāṇasiyaṁ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṁ dhammacakkaṁ pavattitaṁ appaṭivattiyaṁ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṁ, yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn141:4.2: imesaṁ catunnaṁ ariyasaccānaṁ ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ.
root_text.mn141:5.6: Sāriputto, bhikkhave, sotāpattiphale vineti, moggallāno uttamatthe.
root_text.mn141:5.7: Sāriputto, bhikkhave, pahoti cattāri ariyasaccāni vitthārena ācikkhituṁ desetuṁ paññāpetuṁ paṭṭhapetuṁ vivarituṁ vibhajituṁ uttānīkātun”ti.
root_text.mn141:6.2: Idaṁ vatvāna sugato uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṁ pāvisi.
root_text.mn141:7.1: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto acirapakkantassa bhagavato bhikkhū āmantesi:
root_text.mn141:7.3: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṁ.
root_text.mn141:8.1: “Tathāgatena, āvuso, arahatā sammāsambuddhena bārāṇasiyaṁ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṁ dhammacakkaṁ pavattitaṁ appaṭivattiyaṁ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṁ, yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn141:8.2: catunnaṁ ariyasaccānaṁ ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ.
root_text.mn141:9.1: Dukkhassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ, dukkhasamudayassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ, dukkhanirodhassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ.
root_text.mn141:10.2: Jātipi dukkhā, jarāpi dukkhā, maraṇampi dukkhaṁ, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsāpi dukkhā, yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ; saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā.
root_text.mn141:11.2: Yā tesaṁ tesaṁ sattānaṁ tamhi tamhi sattanikāye jāti sañjāti okkanti abhinibbatti khandhānaṁ pātubhāvo āyatanānaṁ paṭilābho,
root_text.mn141:12.2: Yā tesaṁ tesaṁ sattānaṁ tamhi tamhi sattanikāye jarā jīraṇatā khaṇḍiccaṁ pāliccaṁ valittacatā āyuno saṁhāni indriyānaṁ paripāko,
root_text.mn141:13.2: Yā tesaṁ tesaṁ sattānaṁ tamhā tamhā sattanikāyā cuti cavanatā bhedo antaradhānaṁ maccu maraṇaṁ kālaṅkiriyā khandhānaṁ bhedo kaḷevarassa nikkhepo jīvitindriyassupacchedo,
root_text.mn141:14.2: Yo kho, āvuso, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa soko socanā socitattaṁ antosoko antoparisoko,
root_text.mn141:15.2: Yo kho, āvuso, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa ādevo paridevo ādevanā paridevanā ādevitattaṁ paridevitattaṁ,
root_text.mn141:16.2: Yaṁ kho, āvuso, kāyikaṁ dukkhaṁ kāyikaṁ asātaṁ kāyasamphassajaṁ dukkhaṁ asātaṁ vedayitaṁ,
root_text.mn141:17.2: Yaṁ kho, āvuso, cetasikaṁ dukkhaṁ cetasikaṁ asātaṁ manosamphassajaṁ dukkhaṁ asātaṁ vedayitaṁ,
root_text.mn141:18.2: Yo kho, āvuso, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa āyāso upāyāso āyāsitattaṁ upāyāsitattaṁ,
root_text.mn141:19.1: Katamañcāvuso, yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ?
root_text.mn141:19.2: Jātidhammānaṁ, āvuso, sattānaṁ evaṁ icchā uppajjati:
root_text.mn141:19.3: ‘aho vata mayaṁ na jātidhammā assāma; na ca vata no jāti āgaccheyyā’ti.
root_text.mn141:19.10: ‘aho vata mayaṁ na sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā assāma; na ca vata no sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā āgaccheyyun’ti.
root_text.mn141:21.2: Yāyaṁ taṇhā ponobbhavikā nandīrāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.mn141:22.2: Yo tassāyeva taṇhāya asesavirāganirodho cāgo paṭinissaggo mutti anālayo,
root_text.mn141:23.3: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
root_text.mn141:24.2: Yaṁ kho, āvuso, dukkhe ñāṇaṁ, dukkhasamudaye ñāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhe ñāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṁ,
root_text.mn141:26.2: Musāvādā veramaṇī, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇī, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇī, samphappalāpā veramaṇī,
root_text.mn141:27.2: Pāṇātipātā veramaṇī, adinnādānā veramaṇī, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇī,
root_text.mn141:28.2: Idhāvuso, ariyasāvako micchāājīvaṁ pahāya sammāājīvena jīvikaṁ kappeti,
root_text.mn141:29.2: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu anuppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ anuppādāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati,
root_text.mn141:29.3: uppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati,
root_text.mn141:29.4: anuppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ uppādāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati,
root_text.mn141:29.5: uppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati,
root_text.mn141:30.2: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
root_text.mn141:30.5: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ,
root_text.mn141:31.2: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati,
root_text.mn141:31.3: vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati,
root_text.mn141:31.4: pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ …pe…
root_text.mn141:32.1: Tathāgatenāvuso, arahatā sammāsambuddhena bārāṇasiyaṁ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṁ dhammacakkaṁ pavattitaṁ appaṭivattiyaṁ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṁ, yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn141:32.2: imesaṁ catunnaṁ ariyasaccānaṁ ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkamman”ti.
root_text.mn141:32.4: Attamanā te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn141:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.
translation_text.mn141:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn141:2.1: “Near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.
translation_text.mn141:2.2: It is the teaching, advocating, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing of the four noble truths.
translation_text.mn141:3.1: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
translation_text.mn141:4.1: Near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.
translation_text.mn141:4.2: It is the teaching, advocating, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing of the four noble truths.
translation_text.mn141:5.1: Mendicants, you should cultivate friendship with Sāriputta and Moggallāna.
translation_text.mn141:5.2: You should associate with Sāriputta and Moggallāna.
translation_text.mn141:5.3: They’re astute, and they support their spiritual companions.
translation_text.mn141:5.4: Sāriputta is like one who gives birth,
translation_text.mn141:5.5: while Moggallāna is like one who raises the child.
translation_text.mn141:5.6: Sāriputta guides people to the fruit of stream-entry, Moggallāna to the highest goal.
translation_text.mn141:5.7: Sāriputta is able to explain, teach, assert, establish, clarify, analyze, and reveal the four noble truths in detail.”
translation_text.mn141:6.1: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn141:6.2: When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.
translation_text.mn141:7.1: Then soon after the Buddha left, Venerable Sāriputta said to the mendicants,
translation_text.mn141:8.1: “Near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.
translation_text.mn141:8.2: It is the teaching, advocating, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing of the four noble truths.
translation_text.mn141:9.1: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
translation_text.mn141:10.1: And what is the noble truth of suffering?
translation_text.mn141:10.2: Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering.
translation_text.mn141:11.2: The rebirth, inception, conception, regeneration, manifestation of the aggregates, and acquisition of the sense fields of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn141:12.2: The old age, decrepitude, broken teeth, grey hair, wrinkly skin, diminished vitality, and failing faculties of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn141:13.2: The passing away, passing on, disintegration, demise, mortality, death, decease, breaking up of the aggregates, laying to rest of the corpse, and cutting off of the life faculty of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn141:14.2: The sorrow, sorrowing, state of sorrow, inner sorrow, inner deep sorrow in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering.
translation_text.mn141:15.2: The wail, lament, wailing, lamenting, state of wailing and lamentation in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering.
translation_text.mn141:16.2: Physical pain, physical unpleasantness, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from physical contact.
translation_text.mn141:17.2: Mental pain, mental displeasure, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from mind contact.
translation_text.mn141:18.2: The stress, distress, state of stress and distress in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering.
translation_text.mn141:19.1: And what is ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering’?
translation_text.mn141:19.2: In sentient beings who are liable to be reborn, such a wish arises:
translation_text.mn141:19.3: ‘Oh, if only we were not liable to be reborn! If only rebirth would not come to us!’
translation_text.mn141:19.4: But you can’t get that by wishing.
translation_text.mn141:19.5: This is: ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering.’
translation_text.mn141:19.6: In sentient beings who are liable to grow old …
translation_text.mn141:19.9: experience sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, such a wish arises:
translation_text.mn141:19.10: ‘Oh, if only we were not liable to experience sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress! If only sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress would not come to us!’
translation_text.mn141:19.11: But you can’t get that by wishing.
translation_text.mn141:19.12: This is: ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering.’
translation_text.mn141:20.1: And what is ‘in brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering’?
translation_text.mn141:20.2: They are the grasping aggregates that consist of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
translation_text.mn141:20.3: This is called ‘in brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering.’
translation_text.mn141:20.4: This is called the noble truth of suffering.
translation_text.mn141:21.1: And what is the noble truth of the origin of suffering?
translation_text.mn141:21.2: It’s the craving that leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands. That is,
translation_text.mn141:21.3: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for existence, and craving for nonexistence.
translation_text.mn141:21.4: This is called the noble truth of the origin of suffering.
translation_text.mn141:22.1: And what is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering?
translation_text.mn141:22.2: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not clinging to it.
translation_text.mn141:22.3: This is called the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.
translation_text.mn141:23.1: And what is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering?
translation_text.mn141:23.2: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
translation_text.mn141:23.3: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
translation_text.mn141:24.2: Knowing about suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
translation_text.mn141:25.2: Thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.
translation_text.mn141:26.2: Refraining from lying, divisive speech, harsh speech, and talking nonsense.
translation_text.mn141:27.2: Refraining from killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct.
translation_text.mn141:28.2: It’s when a noble disciple gives up wrong livelihood and earns a living by right livelihood.
translation_text.mn141:29.2: It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise.
translation_text.mn141:29.3: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up.
translation_text.mn141:29.4: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise.
translation_text.mn141:29.5: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.
translation_text.mn141:30.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.mn141:30.3: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
translation_text.mn141:30.5: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.mn141:31.2: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn141:31.3: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn141:31.4: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.mn141:31.5: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.mn141:31.7: This is called the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
translation_text.mn141:32.1: Near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.
translation_text.mn141:32.2: It is the teaching, advocating, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing of the four noble truths.”
translation_text.mn141:32.4: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what Sāriputta said.
